title: Hawaiian Ahupua'a Land Management
description: A 60-second lesson on Hawaiian Ahupua'a Land Management.

hook.text: Hawaiians divided land from mountain to sea in wedge-shaped sections. Each slice was a self-sufficient ecosystem.

buildup.text: Ahupua'a integrated forest, farmland, fishponds, and ocean. Resources flowed downhillâ€”water, nutrients, and food.

discovery.text: Taro paddies in mid-elevation fed the population. Fishponds at sea level recycled agricultural runoff into protein.

twist.text: It sustained 1 million Hawaiians on limited island landâ€”a population density rivaling pre-industrial Europe.

climax.text: Ahupua'a is landscape-scale ecological designâ€”watershed thinking that modern sustainability is just rediscovering.

punchline.text: Hawaiians managed ecosystems from mountaintop to ocean floor.

quiz.question: What was unique about the Hawaiian ahupua'a system?
options: It divided land from mountain to sea, integrating forest, farm, and fishpond as one system
It was the first agricultural system to use irrigation canals
It relied exclusively on aquaculture with no land farming
